etymologies: mid 19th century; earliest use found in Jeremy Bentham (1748–1832), philosopher, jurist, and reformer. From ancient Greek ὁριστικός of or for defining (from ὁριστής a person who marks the boundaries, a person who determines (from ὁρίζειν to delimit, bound + -της, suffix forming agent nouns) + -ικός), with omission of initial aspiration under the influence of aoristic
